fields.description:
If Walrus is running on a Eucalyptus Cloud that doesn't have Eucalyptus DNS enabled, bucket naming rules are broken which causes issues with some third party AWS S3 tools.  

As part of the [AWS S3 Bucket Restrictions and Limitations documentation|http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/BucketRestrictions.html], the following rule is expressed:

* Bucket names must not be formatted as an IP address (e.g., 192.168.5.4)

_*NOTE*: This isn't a new restriction.  Looks like its been part of the [AWS S3 Documentation|http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/2006-03-01/dev/BucketRestrictions.html] since the first release - 2006-03-13._
fields.summary: If Eucalyptus DNS is not enabled, AWS compatibility regarding bucket URLs is broken with Walrus

comments.body:
Was able to confirm issue by using Fog 1.10.0: *Non-DNS test against Eucalyptus Walrus* _This fails with the following error message:_ {code} [WARNING] fog: the specified s3 bucket name(192.168.39.102) is not a valid dns name, which will negatively impact performance. For details see: http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/BucketRestrictions.html Excon::Errors::NotFound: Expected(200) <=> Actual(404 Not Found) {code} {code} 1.9.3p194 :031 > storage = Fog::Storage.new({ 1.9.3p194 :032 > :provider => "AWS", 1.9.3p194 :033 > :aws_access_key_id => "", 1.9.3p194 :034 > :aws_secret_access_key => "", 1.9.3p194 :035 > :endpoint => "http://192.168.39.102:8773/services/Walrus", 1.9.3p194 :036 > :region => "eucalyptus"}) => #1048576, :connect_timeout=>60, :headers=>{"User-Agent"=>"fog/1.10.0"}, :instrumentor_name=>"excon", :mock=>false, :nonblock=>true, :read_timeout=>60, :retry_limit=>4, :ssl_ca_file=>"/Users/haroldspencerjr/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p194/gems/excon-0.16.3/data/cacert.pem", :ssl_verify_peer=>true, :write_timeout=>60, :host=>"192.168.39.102", :path=>"/services/Walrus", :port=>"8773", :query=>nil, :scheme=>"http"}, @proxy=nil, @socket_key="192.168.39.102:8773">, @persistent=nil>> 1.9.3p194 :037 > storage.directories [WARNING] fog: the specified s3 bucket name(192.168.39.102) is not a valid dns name, which will negatively impact performance. For details see: http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/BucketRestrictions.html Excon::Errors::NotFound: Expected(200) <=> Actual(404 Not Found) request => {:chunk_size=>1048576, :connect_timeout=>60, :headers=>{"User-Agent"=>"fog/1.10.0", "Date"=>"Thu, 16 May 2013 16:56:23 +0000", "Authorization"=>"AWS AIJS9LKC2C3OWBIEWYARU:P/GPDtkAp/I4gSQcXo/v9okvJxU=", "Host"=>"192.168.39.102:8773"}, :instrumentor_name=>"excon", :mock=>false, :nonblock=>true, :read_timeout=>60, :retry_limit=>4, :ssl_ca_file=>"/Users/haroldspencerjr/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p194/gems/excon-0.16.3/data/cacert.pem", :ssl_verify_peer=>true, :write_timeout=>60, :host=>"192.168.39.102", :path=>"/192.168.39.102", :port=>"8773", :query=>nil, :scheme=>"http", :expects=>200, :idempotent=>true, :method=>"GET", :response_block=>#} response => #404 Not Foundunknownunknown", @headers={"Content-Type"=>"text/plain; Hey [~sjones],

Thanks for the suggestion.  

I was using fog 1.10.0 and tried it, and got the following error:

{code}
1.9.3p194 :011 >   storage = Fog::Storage.new({
1.9.3p194 :012 >       :provider => "AWS",
1.9.3p194 :013 >       :aws_access_key_id => "ACCESS-KEY",
1.9.3p194 :014 >       :aws_secret_access_key => "SECRET-KEY",
1.9.3p194 :015 >       :endpoint => "http://192.168.39.102:8773/services/Walrus",
1.9.3p194 :016 >       :path_style => "true" })
ArgumentError: Unrecognized arguments: path_style
	from /Users/haroldspencerjr/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p194/gems/fog-1.10.0/lib/fog/core/service.rb:214:in `validate_options'

	from /Users/haroldspencerjr/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p194/bin/irb:16:in `<main>'
{code}

When I removed the "path_style" option and changed the endpoint to "http://walrus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/services/Walrus", everything worked.

I installed fog 1.11.1, and got the following:

I get this same error if I use the DNS name or IP address for endpoint.  

_*NOTE* From this testing, it looks like fog 1.11.1 doesn't work against Eucalyptus, but I need to validate further._

Hope this helps.

Just confirmed.  

Fog 1.11.1 works with Cloud Controller (i.e. EC2), but not with Walrus (i.e. S3) for Eucalyptus 3.2.2; need to test against Eucalyptus 3.3

I will update https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/wiki/Fog accordingly.

Confirmed.

Fog 1.11.1 works with the Cloud Controller (i.e. EC2), but not with Walrus (i.e. S3) for Eucalyptus 3.3.0: the same as mentioned above.  The error that shows up is as follows:

{code}
1.9.3p194 :115 >   storage = Fog::Storage.new({

1.9.3p194 :119 >       :endpoint => "http://<IP or DNS name>:8773/services/Walrus",
1.9.3p194 :120 >       :path_style => "<true or false>" })

Found exact same 404, while working with fog on a DNS enabled cloud running 3.3.0 with git commit ID 3485d8ce48e63e9818d20c0d92abc4e344dbda70 , this code has the DNS fixes that [~decker] did for split-horizon. Fog code {code} #!/usr/bin/ruby require 'rubygems' require 'fog' @aws_access_key_id = "L13NBTS8XHTUN3T8IZ8AB" @aws_secret_access_key = "ChU9iVjifEAjfYTc1zpw1K2Mb4RW6prUpNkLBSrH" @s3_endpoint = "http://eucalyptus.mycloud.jeevanullas.org:8773/services/Walrus/" # Connect to your Eucalyptus Cloud. storage = Fog::Storage.new( :provider => "AWS", :aws_access_key_id => @aws_access_key_id, This looks like an issue with Fog. Can we get a wire trace to see what the raw HTTP request looks like to Walrus? It looks like Fog thinks the bucket name is the IP. That will certainly fail if it isn't formatting the request properly.

Looking at the log output more, it looks like Fog is issuing a GET for eucalyptus.xxx.com/ That is not a walrus endpoint. It should be walrus.xxxxxxx if DNS is enabled or eucalpytus.xxx.yyy.com/services/Walrus if not using DNS. Also, it looks like Fog is not setting the host header properly--it should not have the port in the host header value.

What version of Fog and are you using? We can try to reproduce the issue, but I suspect this is a Fog configuration issue rather than a Walrus issue.
Linking due to them relating to DNS requirements for Walrus

Hey [~zhill],

Check [the link above|https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-6208?focusedCommentId=45832&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-45832].  I lay out what versions of Fog, and what I used for the endpoint.  Hope this helps.  Please let me know if you need additional information.

This is, in fact, a new restriction since AWS now requires that all buckets adhere to DNS naming standards.

AWS updates S3 documentation and API without versioning it. All carry the same initial version.

If you look for examples of people explaining what used to be acceptable bucket names, it will become clear. For instance,

http://www.newvem.com/amazon-cloud-s3-bucket-creation-policies-and-guidelines/

Also, in the US location, it is acceptable to have buckets that do NOT conform to DNS for historical reasons:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/UG/CreatingaBucket.html

"Bucket names must comply with the following requirements.

Can contain lowercase letters, numbers, periods (.), underscores (_), and dashes (-).

Must start with a number or letter.

Must be between 3 and 255 characters long.

Must not be formatted as an IP address (e.g., 192.168.5.4) .

To conform with DNS requirements, we recommend the following, additional guidelines when creating bucket names."

This reads "recommend," not required.

The issues with one operation working and others failing is due to EUCA-7666. If bucket listing works then others would not due to the way DNS hostnames were checked in Walrus. If using Walrus DNS (i.e. walrus.dnsdomain.com) then the service path can not be included or it will be treated as a bucket 'services' and an object 'Walrus<+whatever actual bucket you wanted>'. The bug in EUCA-7666 caused ListAllMyBuckets (GET / on the service) requests to fail without the /services/Walrus path, but including that path fails all other DNS requests for Walrus because a request sent to: _bucket1.walrus.domain.com/services/Walrus_ is actually a request for object 'services/Walrus' in the 'bucket1' bucket.

The fix for EUCA-7666 is in the testing branch and will be in 3.4.0. To configure Fog, set the endpoint to: _walrus.mydomain.com:8773_ if you want to use DNS, or:
_mydomain.com:8773/services/Walrus_ if DNS is not configured or you don't want to use it. You cannot combine the walrus component DNS name and the service path.

The path-style (walrus.domain/bucket) vs hosted-style (bucket.walrus.domain) is irrelevant if you are using walrus DNS but only path-style is supported if not using DNS.

With regard to bucket names that are IPs, we have 2 options:
1. Use the S3 global standard, which is DNS-compliant and prohibits IPs as bucket names.
2. Allow the S3-US-standard names, which are not DNS compliant, with the caveat that these types of bucket names can *only* be accessed via path-style requests (e.g. http://walrus.domain.com:8773/10.1.1.1, where "10.1.1.1" is a bucket) and explain to customers that differences. This is still AWS-compliant but means that some buckets are only accessible via one type of request instead of both path and virtual-hosted.

If going with option #2 enables Fog to work out of the box, I'm inclined to go with #2 and allow buckets that look like IPs. It's a trivial change in the WalrusManager.java file--there is an explicit check for IP-like bucketnames that we can just disable.

[~neil]? [~wwannemacher]? [~hspencer]?

I am in favor of less restrictive naming.

Alright, [~wwannemacher], can you take a look at removing the IP-type bucket name restriction? See: [WalrusManager.checkBucketName()|http://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/blob/master/clc/modules/object-storage/src/main/java/com/eucalyptus/objectstorage/WalrusManager.java#L528]

That should resolve this issue, and combined with the fixes for EUCA-7666, should get Fog working reasonably well.
[~zhill], [~neil] - I can remove it outright, that is easy enough, but do you think it would be beneficial to leave in a hook so that it could be configurable later (potentially by AZ?)
Configurable would be good, but it will have to be cloud-global because Walrus doesn't have the concept of AZs.

[~zhill]/[~wwannemacher],

I agree with [~neil] on this - it should be less restrictive.  I think the main thing here is to have this issue and EUCA-7666 be resolved so that we can get things working with Fog.  Just curious, do we know if these fixes will help things work better with [s3cmd|https://github.com/s3tools/s3cmd] as well?

[~hspencer], yes, if DNS is enabled and configured, this should make s3cmd easier because no service path is needed. Without component-DNS (or DNS-delegation as it is called in the configuration of Euca) things are basically the same, but DNS will be much better.

added property - walrus.bucketnamesrequirednscompliance which defaults to false. When false, buckets are allowed to have names that look like IP addresses (i.e. 63.121.201.17), when true, the name would be rejected. Additional comments / fixes related to behavior of walrus with DNS enabled were worked on in EUCA-7666

When the property is set to true i see:
2013-10-10 18:56:04: PUT: The specified bucket is not valid: 1.2.3.4: InvalidBucketName: [object Object]

Otherwise it is accepted as usual.
